Problem:
Consider a linear operator \\( L \\) acting on a function \\( u(x) \\) defined by an integral transform \\( L[u(x)] = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} k(x, s) u(s) ds \\), where \\( k(x, s) \\) is the kernel of the transformation. Suppose we introduce a perturbation function \\( p(x) \\) which modifies \\( u(x) \\) to \\( v(x) = u(x) + p(x) \\).

Given the transformed function \\( L[w(x)] \\), can we determine precisely the sequences or types of modifications (both \\( p(x) \\) and \\( q(x) \\)) applied to \\( u(x) \\), merely by analyzing the outcome?
Explanation: Since \\( L[w(x)] \\) equals \\( L[u(x)] + L[p(x)] + L[q(x)] \\), multiple combinations of \\( p(x) \\) and \\( q(x) \\) could yield the same cumulative transformation effect on \\( u(x) \\). This overlap makes it impossible to uniquely determine the specific modifications from the transformed result alone.
